commentBody:
Nice puzzle. Very solid fill with no names or obscure trivia.

The SW was tough for me because I entered PLEB for PEON, but everything else was smooth.

My only gripes were its lower difficulty and high number of black squares.

8/10.
Lots of fun and unexpected things here. It looked impossible at first and then suddenly it was done. I didn't know NERFING but now I do.

Not a big challenge but fun and zesty choices. I feel the “yeah, I’m sure” has a little John Wick energy. And I can’t remember where but another puzzle I did recently also used “nerf” in the same context. I don’t know if I would have gotten it so quickly otherwise.
Pretty sure that Friday and Tuesday this week were switched. Breezed through this one and Thursday as well. Still reeling from Tuesday.
LETSSAY I KINDASORTA KEPTITREAL.  YEAHIMSURE.

I enjoyed this puzzle and found it just the right difficulty for Friday - I solved it in my average time for this time in the week.

BANC and SPITBALL were new to me, and I had to look up the four or so trivia clues there were (what a nice change from yesterday with its excessive 20+ proper nouns!).
Pretty grid.
A very welcome and enjoyable crossword puzzle after yesterday's crosspropernouns puzzle
I enjoyed this one!
And that, my friends, is how you construct a Friday puzzle
Well constructed and very enjoyable. Had that great Friday quality of feeling overwhelming at first and it slowly whittles away to an excellent sculpted solve.
Much better than yesterday's

Wow. This was a “I’ll never get it” that somehow came together. Good one. 

My music came with: “6:48 slower than your average.” 

Are they now only averaging since the start of the streak or something? In my case, I rarely make it through a week, So it’s apples and oranges. Should I say, L’ORANGE? 

I did enjoy seeing how I compared to me on other Friday puzzles.
Man top right took me forever. Great puzzle.
The SPITBALLing I did in grammar school produced exactly zero bright ideas.
Really nice one, enjoyed that

Now *this* is a crossword puzzle!

I had so little filled in across that I just knew downs would come to the rescue. They didn’t.

Then, sudden inspiration struck again and again until I was suddenly in the southeast corner thinking it was all over for me. Surely, FUR wasn’t the [bear necessity]. It was! I only knew NERFING because of a NYT Gen Z quiz (my kids aren’t big gamers so I don’t know the lingo). 

I feel like an absolute genius for this smooth solve. WHOKNEW? 🤣 AARP won’t get me yet!

Unfortunately, I get exactly one day of this feeling because, like LSD, Saturday’s puzzle will surely change my perspective. I’ll return to my usual status of cruciverbal PEON.

Welp, I have a HOTDATE with my electric blanket because it’s so cold. 

Adeus, as minhas palavras amigas!
I know that I'm older than most solvers (78) and this puzzle took me back a few decades. I really enjoyed it! Really great!

It’s been a minute since I  touched the grids. 
Just did Thursday and Friday. 

Definitely enjoyed tonight’s (and solved much faster) than yesterday’s ‘trickless’?’ Puzzle. 

My favorite clue was the misdirect on “component of many a trial”. Given I there was a “court seat” clue BANC on a cross of that entry. 

Cool grid design

I was surprised with Tuesday and Wednesday this week - Thursday being Thursday did not surprise me at all, and then this Friday beauty, complete with a few old favorites I haven’t seen in months; SISAL for one.

The misdirections were good, (“Rivet” the verb, not “Rivet” the noun!) and COURT SEAT / COURT STATEMENT was simple but effective obfuscation that sapped my confidence.

Enjoyable and approachable without anything overtly narcissistic.

Thank you!

A much better experience today. Here's the thing.
Hard puzzles don't bother me. Tricky clues don't bother me. This isn't the easy-peasy syndicated crossword next to The Family Circus. But you can just tell when parts of the grid are forced, or when a computer might have helped put the grid together. Yesterday's puzzle had that problem, today's did not.

Really pretty hard for me and a good Friday puzzle.  Both halves of the top gave me some trouble, and the bottom wasn't a picnic either.

Ultimately solvable, fair, and enjoyable.  I don't think I have any nits to pick at the moment.  Give me time.  ;)

I read the constructor note; I'll never quite understand why anyone cares what a crossword puzzle grid LOOKS like.  It has nothing to do with the game.

This puzzle might be the highlight of the week so far, except maybe that fine if misplaced Tuesday.  Thanks.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

Sometimes surfing doesn’t refer to the Internet, and seniors doesn’t mean students! But trials aren’t always in front of a jury. Nice combination of straightforward and tricky, and I didn’t have a breakdown to end the work wk.

After two days of suffering (finished solving both Wednesday and Thursday the next morning - thanks, time difference, for letting me sleep on it without missing out on a gold star!), this felt like a breath of fresh air. A perfect Friday! Just the right amount of struggling.

A wildebeest is an antelope. Who gnu?

(Should've read "Graze Anatomy.")
I liked this puzzle a lot. I needed all the hints and still got stuck in the northeast corner. Not sure about LASE otherwise it’s all good to me! Nice one!

After a tough beginning to the week something clicked and I finished this puzzle in half me average Friday time.  Not saying it was easy, it did take a few passes to get everything filled in.  Nice puzzle…
Why the definitive L'ORANGE when you clue "un cognac"? That seems to go against some rules (conventions? Norms?).
A fun and challenging crossword with difficult yet realistic clues. I really clicked with this one. Thanks, Robert, for an enjoyable puzzle.

Puzzles like this make me grateful for the app, because this would otherwise be a two-eraser solve. I filled in maybe five answers in my first pass through, and I’m guessing three of those were later changed. But thanks to a lack of proper names and some really excellent clueing, I was able to wend my way through and earn my first lookup-free Friday gold star. Thanks, Robert!

Nice puzzle--a fun solve that paid (more than) fair returns on the opportunity cost of the time spent with it.

Rather the opposite of yesterday's, I'd say.

The perfect Friday puzzle, and what a breath of fresh air. So it *is* possible to construct a grid without 20 obscure proper names. WHE KNEW?

I breezed through it but it felt like there was a genie sitting on my shoulder this morning. Or rather, a jinni since the Quran is in the house today.

Lovely. Yesterday used all the nouns that didn’t get through the sieve and today we got the almost  pure puzzle. 

Thanks.

47D [Start to work?]--
Once again, the Hegemony of the nine-to-five.
My "weekend" this week has been Wed. and yesterday--hence my greater presence on Wordplay. So it was Thurs. night which filled me with ANGST, thinking "How the hell will I get the cheesecake baked, cooled, cut, and plated before dinner tomorrow?" 
Managed to get the puzzle done in the few minutes I have to sip coffee before this PEON sets off to make the SAUCES.
Ciao, belle!

Nice Friday puzzle. Not particularly easy for me, of course, and did have to cheat a bit to get through it, but lots of nice 'aha' moments when I finally worked things out. And... a rare early morning when the puzzle was not my primary focus. On that note - a couple of answer history searches (and a puzzle find) today. First search was for SNOWING. Was very surprised to see that that string of letters has only ever appeared by itself - never in a longer answers. And... never in a Shortz era puzzle. And then - one 21 letter answer find led to a Sunday puzzle from January 15, 2012 by Finn Vigeland with the title: "Weather report." That 21 letter clue and answer: "Weather comment represented visually by this puzzle's circled letters" ITSRAININGCATSANDDOGS And then there were a number of circled letters in 6 long down answers. One example: (P)H(O)N(O)GRAPHNEE(D)(L)(E) Here's the Xword Info link: https://xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=1/15/2012&g=66&d=A I'll be out on the back porch. See you later. ...

I was getting really grumpy with this puzzle as I stared at a nearly empty grid for ages - grrr, this just too difficult, obscure, blah blah...

Yet when I finally finished it most of the answers are things I am familiar with. I was undone by the clever clueing. The fault was all mine, of course.

Once again I learnt some new expressions - hit me up, pinky swear, on a lark (I only know FOR a lark) and one I could've done without knowing - spitball (eww). Every day is a school day for me here!

i have to stop doing these first thing in the morning  LOL. tough puzzle, i only filled 3-4 answers on my first pass--i really needed the prompts from the column to get going 😭

i was almost always a couple letters off from every single phrase answer, which got me really stuck (and frustrated!) a few times--still a satisfying finish with clever clues though!
I liked this Friday! Not too America-centric which made it easier for me!

Lots of proper crosswordy clues instead of names, but still hard!
Only seen onesies with zips, and snaps are press studs which I would 'undo'.
I didn't know SPITBALL (nice!) or BANC, AARP, STEINS, SHORE, TOTS (how is that squirts?) PINKY swear, METS, cable channel, CNN clue, and I also think of FOR a LARK, not heard of a PARTY BUS, and KINDASORTA, but knew all the rest, and revealed a few. OK for a foreigner.

Four minutes off my Friday best and ten minutes below my average confirms my impression that, while it looked challenging at first, it turned out to be easier than expected.

Still, plenty of fun clues, clean fill, so no complaints.

Thanks!

Where was the clunky fill?
Where was all the crosswordese?
What just happened?

Seemed so sticky, but every
single answer opened up two more.

Loved the mood, and flew through this puppy
so fast my tea is still hot.

Thank you Robert. 

Happy Friday all!

Strands Thread.  No spoilers please until after the View All Replies button: 


Strands #313
“They're inseparable”
🟡🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵🔵🔵
🔵

This style of Strands make for an easier solve.

Looking at the comments, 
and seeing so many with a similar 
solving experience, 
something fascinates me.

On Monday, we read the clues literally.
We know the misdirects will be made apparent.
So it’s a fill-in-the-blank kind of solve.

By Friday, 
We read the clues as riddles,
noticing  the play on words, and
running with the misdirects.
Put on our Friday hats and run with it!

So today was a just a couple minutes 
over my Monday time. 

Are others noticing that too?
That solve times don’t vary much after
solving for years?
Got totally stuck on the WSW segment, saw the drug trial hint in the column and the rest fell into place within a minute.

As soon as I saw "This is _" and noticed the answer had three letters, I heard the voice of the late James Earl Jones and immediately filled in CNN. 

Then it was a bit of a struggle for a while to get a few more toeholds, until finally I was left with just the NE corner. But then a lot of answers just popped into my head. BANC, for example, is old crosswordese to me, though it was new to quite a few younger solvers.

Wasn't BENDYSTRAW a recent entry? And why did High Chairs have a question mark? 

I think I appreciated the puzzle more after I completed it than while actually working it! And, as many have stated, it was easier than Tuesday's beast.

Knew this puzzle would have some Real Possibilities after first plugging in SEOUL/AARP/SAUCES.  "BLESS me", I said, "I CAN'T 'EEN fill this in fast enough".  Nicely done and thanks. 

[Documentarian's credo.]

KEEPINITREEL

Did anybody really think "the won" could refer to "winnings" in Las Vegas??
I was so sure "private watering hole" would be "minibar" before I had any crossing letters. Coming here from the stricter British cryptic crosswords, this clue isn't grammatically correct if the answer is "canteen": "Private's watering hole" would make it refer to the soldier's tin - but anyway "watering hole" doesn't really fit for a water bottle in my view.
Sorry, too much moaning, always grateful for a decent puzzle! Thanks!

This one felt strong, solid, had a classic feel – like it’s not going to be out of date anytime soon – and just had the stamp of quality.  I never got the feeling that Robert’s priority was in impressing, rather, it was in making the puzzle a good experience for the solver.

To me, there was just the right combination of resistance and openings, of ANGST and YEAH I’M SURE.  

Highlights for me:
•	The meta column one, which reads SPICY SAUCES, and with the clue for the latter word consisting of two spicy sauces.
•	The lovely answers WREST and WHORL.
•	The DOOK sighting of NOONES.
•	Post-solve learning that the horses in polo may play until age 18 or 20, and, according to Britannica, are judged to be 60- to 75-percent of a player’s ability.
•	The aha when the answer to [Component of many a trial] hit me.
•	After reading in Robert’s notes that he likes to make aesthetically pleasing grid designs, looking at his past puzzles, and being reminded of the melt-my-heart beautiful 7/22/23 puzzle design – worth a look, IMO.

Robert, filling in your creation was a rich experience for me. I’m so glad for having done it.  Thank you!
Most fun puzzle in quite awhile imo.

Breathing, blinking, and breaks! I love that, Sam.
The B-attitudes for solving.

It is a nice grid, Robert.
I was flummoxed in the NW corner to start, but then found answers in the NE, and pinwheeled around clockwise, the fill flowing in.

BENDY STRAW gave me a chuckle, since we had a long discussion on that a short while back.

The informal vernacular phrases KEPT IT REAL, while there was a BLESSed paucity of pop culture, sports, and names. Or so it seemed to me. The slangy, idiomatic stuff may make it hard for our international solvers. KINDA SORTA.

Not too hard, not too soft.... just right! 

I had [This is] FUN for 18A... that threw me off. It took me a while to figure out what 1D and 2D were, my brain just glitched looking at those words with the F U there (and no IO either)  😄

I loved the clue [Bear necessity?] even though I had "den" in there too long (nerding seemed right, lol).

LETSdAY, LETSdAY, ...... ok SAY.

Guess which fill we labored over.

Nice one Robert, thank you
376-day streak. First time I've felt compelled to compliment a perfect puzzle.
Really enjoyed this one, first pass yielded very little, but it gradually filled in with fair clueing and and some fun twists.  Nice change after some of the recent puzzles

Like others have said, it started out a bit daunting, but ended up taking less time -- for me 20% less -- than average.

Early on, I had 22A/20D as IAMCERTAIN/CALM.  I'm glad I thought to remove that pretty quickly, as it would have been an obstacle.

I understand "watering hole" is a thing so I guess that allows us to accept that a vessel that holds water is a hole?  The canteen has a hole where the water comes out, but the hole is not the canteen.  I think all the pedantry in the comments is starting to wear off on me.

Like others have said, it started out a bit daunting, but ended up taking less time -- for me 20% less -- than average.

Early on, I had the 22A/20D cross as IAMCERTAIN/CALM.  I'm glad I thought to remove that pretty quickly, as it would have been an obstacle.  The possibility of 1D ending in the letter "i" strongly influenced that decision.

I understand "watering hole" is a thing so I guess that allows us to accept that a vessel that holds water is a hole?  The canteen has a hole where the water comes out, but the hole is not the canteen.  I think all the pedantry in the comments is starting to wear off on me.
I always take a moment to admire the Friday and Saturday grids before I start solving. And I agree, today's was very pleasing. Fun solve too.

My KINDA/SORTA puzzle---not a single person's name in the entire grid! What a nice change from yesterday. Seemed like a solid Friday to me, albeit quite gentle.

Having nothing else to add ... please recommend this post if you think the U.S. should annex Ontario ... and should also decree that Rush is an American band. @Byron
Great puzzle! Tough one for me but every clue made sense once solved. Auspicious start to the solving weekend!

Perfect Friday puzzle. Just challenging enough; fresh, clever ideas. Two quibbles. Don't we say "who knew" when we are surprised by some bit of information? I don't see it as a sarcastic response to the obvious. And I don't think "spicy" has the negative connotations that "salacious" does. Also, just one day without a gaming clue--please.
TGIF!  Water is back on in Richmond and Robert Logan gave us a solid Friday puzzle. Kinda sorta wonderful!

I will grudgingly admit that I liked this puzzle -- all in all a very enjoyable solving experience, but I was done in by 18A (I had this is FUN --what else could it be?) and I'm still a little annoyed by the real answer. 

As for 32D, to be gramatically consistent, I think the clue should have read:

Grand Marnier ingredient avec LE cognac.
That is a pretty cool puzzle.  Difficult but defintely not unsolvable.

A Goldilocks opinion:

Tuesday's puzzle was a bit harder than the typical Tuesday.

Wednesday's and Thursday's were a bit easier.

Today's was just right!
Lovely Friday: baffling at first glance and slowly and continually opening itself up to the intrepid solver.

Nice job, Robert Logan!
Smooth as butter!
This is the first Friday puzzle I solved independently (no Google, no dictionary, no thesaurus)! It is going to be a good day!

That was chewy; a real Friday head scratcher. Took me quite a while to find my way in. Naturally enough 18 A and 38A were unknown to me, but got there in the end with the crosses. I’d also never come across 23D before. Is that meant to be an encouraging phrase? 
All in all very pleasing. I’m with Sam and the 3 B’s. Gets me through the day.

I still love Friday puzzles, but this one was chewy! Fair at the end but rife with chances for confident errors, like KNOWS for 39D, DEN for 43A, and - - - - EVE for 17A. Those had to surrender slowly to realities on the crosses.

Had trouble getting started, but then it went really quickly for a Friday. Highlight was filling in the final square: the middle letter of CNN. I was really struggling with 18A as I had wanted a vowel there, but then the voice came out of the depths of my memory and there it was.

As many others have said before me, this really felt like a “perfect” Friday puzzle. Beautiful grid, clever and challenging clues and fill. Thank you, Robert Logan!

Thanks also to Sam for yet another excellent, relatable column. Sam’s fresh and thoughtful commentary is, for me, often the perfect complement to any puzzle, regardless of difficulty or day of the week. Extra credit for humor and humanity, Today, the three B’s: breathing, blinking, and breaks…my solving experience in a nutshell.

I was misled by the "classic spelling"...I put in QURAN, which was more than No Help At All.  
I know we just saw that NERFING business, but it didn't really stick with me...
AS A LARK misled me quite effectively for a good while.

I also did my favorite screw-up, entering an answer in the wrong space--(both the wrong numeral and wrong direction!  Now, that's real talent!....  Robbie Burns was  BONNIE Poet, was he not?)

I just refused to renew our long-time AARP membership because they have thrown in with United Healthcare to offer and advertise a Medicare Advantage Plan under their aegis--violating any principles or integrity that supposedly guided the Association.

Loved it!  I had almost nothing on my first pass with the acrosses.  Guessed PONIES for 12 A correctly, that's about it.  But then (having dressed babies in onesies many times), I got UNSNAPS for 3D, and the rest of the puzzle unsnapped for me one cross at a time.  Fun way to start my Friday morning!  Thank you Robert Logan.
Delightful puzzle with wonderfully fresh answers. Half the fun is the unexpected turns the clues are offering.

Lots of false starts on this. "Sure I'm sure" and "sorta kinda", entered with great confidence early on, really messed me up for a long time. The BENDY STRAW and the PINKY swear were foreign territory for me.

And utter blankness, despite many correct crosses, on my national poet as a PEASANT poet. I'll spare you my dissertation on why that's nonsense, but the clue was fair enough, given that it seems the concept is out there. 

Last to fall was [Unclaimed]---I looked at NO_NES for a ridiculously long, and went through the alphabet twice, before the penny dropped.
Wonderful puzz! This is the kind of puzz that keeps me coming back! Hit the spot!
Wow. I fell so in love with LATRINE for “Private watering hole” that it messed me up for a long time. Very thankful I learned “nerfing” (the hard way) from a recent puzzle…

I too looked forlornly at all the first-pass blanks that remained. Not much help from the shorties, either... alas.
Then came a stab: I threw in "LORANGE" in desperation, and found myself building out and around the southwest [or should I say the "sud-ouest"?]
Slowly I emerged triumphant, but the "three- B's" adage helped. So did going slowly, as in the French adage "Petit a petit, l'oiseau fait son nid"--- [Little by little, the bird makes its nest]
The puzzle was fun, especially after quitting late last night and resuming with the aid of morning coffee.
Thanks!

Whoa, who knew about ponies!? I think this'll really improve my polo game. 

All this time I've been playing on a lark.





L'orange you glad I didn't say l'banana?

I also started with “horses” rather than PONIES (like ad absurdum). WHOKNEW? Well, I’m just SPITBALLing here, but probably many! 
This puzzle was full of phrases in the current vernacular that you just had to figure out. 
Did someone hear the PLEAS of the solvers who complain about arcane knowledge and trivia?
I’m not in their number, but I enjoyed the puzzle. It’s KINDASORTA fun to think in a different way.

I absolutely flew through this one - and didn't even have coffee this morning. I doubt I could have gone much faster if I'd been copying off the answer key. It was definitely a "same wavelength" experience for me today. Thanks for the fun!

I agree with so many others that this is a perfect Friday puzzle.  A good workout, doable, and no names.   

As for Tuesday, I think it was a good puzzle - just run on the wrong day.  Not the fault of the constructor!  The degree of challenge did make me check the calendar to see if the weekend had arrived.

Here’s a tip for people who are intimidated and struggle with Friday puzzles -like me. It might be obvious or sacrilegious to some. 

Solve the easy mode (I get it via email in the mornings ) and then solve the regular mode. It’s fun to see some of the variations in clues and I’m always surprised how quickly I forget an answer.

What a fun fill, and a very doable Friday to boost my confidence in my new years resolution to get through more full weeks of puzzles! Enjoyed the reference to Robbie Burns, especially approaching Burns Night. Thanks to the constructor for a delightful morning coffee solve.
in re to 12A. In an old "Honeymooners" episode Norton mispronounces "polo ponies" as one word (emphasis on the second O). It then becomes a running gag through the show.

Lots of fun language in this one.  I always like WHORL.  

I also got along with the cluing.  Lots of blanks at first like all Fridays but I was able to grind.  Northwest corner fell into place first after replacing JUICY with SPICY.  Then SWEDEN gave me a leg up in the northeast corner. KINDASORTA (which I really like) was a big help across the middle/southeast corner. 

A really lovely puzzle with hardly anything boring or that was a stretch.
That was fun. Perfect Friday puzzle. Got hung up on the SE corner, but I got up, grabbed my second cup of coffee, and when I sat back down it all fell into place.
STONES "set in a ring" made me think of Stonehenge before jewelry. Clearly, I've been watching too much Discovery Channel.

I don't get why so many people don't like proper names in puzzle answers. This one had proper names in the clues. What's the difference? Either you know that person / fact / definition or you don't. I'd argue that some proper names are more familiar than some words. I actually l like learning about people in puzzles. Yes, I, like many middle-aged solvers, have a gap in my knowledge of 2000s popular music, but I don't mind learning about it now. Like many of my nerdy colleagues, I don't follow American football, but it's probably a good idea to know a few of the major stars in the sport. This puzzle was a little tougher than the average Friday for me, and that's okay too! Cheers!
Kinda sorta wacky. But fun once I managed to change my perspective, even without a hit.

As a relative newbie, I just want to say this was right in my wheelhouse for a Friday. Just enough to make me stretch my brain...I learned a few things...I felt that glorious sense of "AHA!" when something clicked. This has reinvigorated my love for the game. Thank you Robert Logan!
This was such a fun puzzle. Enjoyable from start to finish!
Weak tea.
Somebody definitely dropped the pile of puzzles on the way to the printer this week and got the days mixed up!
Is this week’s theme jumbled difficulty? If so I am outraged / delighted by the audacity / courage of the editors to endlessly confound / entertain me!

Still too many weak clues. Bad spellings, inconsistency. NYT putting out high school crosswords. 8d 35a for glaring examples but just generally unsatisfactory. I’d give it a B+ if it were an 11th grade assignment.
Great puzzle. Had NSA for way too long at 4D, which led to SLUNK for 1A and blockaded the NW all morning.
"Stones" "set in a ring" is also something you see in the bluer corners of the Internet.

I immediately heard James Earl Jones’ voice when I read “This is …” but hesitated to fill it in on the first round. Fortunately everything else fell into place pretty quickly - the polar opposite of yesterday’s. You win some, you lose some I guess.
Whorl was a new one for me.  Interesting puzzle lots of blinking to get through this one!!!!   Sam you’re right!!

Wow, feeling genius as I cruised through today’s puzzle!   
Although, Tuesday’s puzzle seemed like a Thursday and Friday’s was like a Wednesday, but Monday was like a …..
Regardless, it was fun to dominate!!!

Loved it.
I'm surprised Sam doesn't hear KINDA SORTA more often; I prolly say the inversion ("sorta kinda") almost daily. FALSETTOS has a therapy session built around it to the point where I consider it the actual name of the song.
==========
[WHIZZER, spoken]
Marvin at the Psychiatrist, a three-part mini opera. Part One.​

[MENDEL]
Do you love him?

[MARVIN]
Sorta kinda

[MENDEL]
Do you need him?

[MARVIN]
Sorta, kinda
He makes me smile a lot
Especially at mealtime
It makes me feel I'm sort of smart

Weird photo at the head of the Wordplay blog, BTW.
Presumably, the person pictured is thinking, "Hey, someone has stolen the lenses from the right side of my binoculars!"
Veni, vidi, solvi

Kudos to you all who breezed through. One nit: why the question mark in the clue for 6A?  Those are actual high chairs. There’s no play on words or double entendre there. That “?” actually kept me from solving 10D for a while since I refused to start it with the too-obvious L. (10D, meanwhile, was a fun clue and perfect use of “?”)

I like how he snuck a l’orange in there.
A smooth puzzle, engagingly quick solve.

Comments poll:
If you think “whorl” should rhyme with “girl”  hit Recommend.
If you think “whorl” should rhyme with “moral” hit Flag, and select the reason of your choice.

(I’m kind of curious to see if this comment gets pulled!)
kinda sorta easy

Perfect Friday feel to me. Lovely misdirects that worked themselves out. 3D was my way into the grid. As a mother of three, I have definitely UNSNAPped my fair share of onesies 🤣 
I completed this one last night following an unexpected evacuation warning alert. We are approximately 20 miles south of the closest fire (Palisades Fire), so we were confused as to why we got an alert. We walked out front and several neighbors had wandered out as well to see what was going on. We noticed a plume of smoke extremely close. One of our neighbors had a fire start in their kitchen while they weren’t home. Firefighters were able to cut into her roof and put the fire out within 5 minutes of their arrival. We got a follow up emergency alert that it was accidentally sent to the whole county but was only intended for the Kenneth Fire. It was completely coincidental that we had a fire so close to us. Needless to say, everyone was shaken up. I turned to the crossword puzzle as soon as it came out and it completely calmed me down in a way like nothing else can. So thank you, Robert Logan, for saving my sanity on an otherwise crazy, emotional roller coaster of a day. I appreciate you and all constructors out there for making each of my days just a little brighter 🥹
Very reasonable clues and answers today. Loved KINDASORTA and LSD. Very clever cluing.

I enjoyed this one a lot. 51 across and 25 across were my favourite ones. Very happy that I finished within 40 minutes. Thanks for your work on it will, really enjoyed doing this on my Friday evening! 

I solved the Friday 1/10/2025 New York Times Daily Crossword in 37:05!
Great puzzle. I loved the southeast region of this grid, with fun answers like PARTYBUS, KINDASORTA, BENDYSTRAW, WAITASEC and PINKY(swear) intersecting. Nice work to the constructor!

Well, I'm not going to say it was a STROLL but once I swapped horses to PONIES (WHO KNEW?), I was at least on a _ _ROLL, but not of the PARTYBUS variety, unfortunately. Har! 

Only a small snag here and there, like God knows before God BLESS and not wanting to accept OKD. I was never going to get NERFING without the crosses, and that worked out just fine. 

For some reason, even things I had no idea about worked out, like METS. I was like, shrug, sounds like a METS thing, even though I know almost nothing of baseball—other than when the Milwaukee Brewers went to the World Series in 1982.

Not quite a personal best but very close. Zero ANGST! 

In KINDASORTA related news, my first and only PARTYBUS experience to date was at age 51 with most of the revelers being in their 30s. It was a blast, but no Grand Marnier. I generally prefer my entertainment shaken, not rolled.

Never thought I’d finish today’s crossword - think I got one almost certain answer on my first pass! Very satisfying once I cracked it though - enjoyed that one even if it did take a while!

After being ill with the VID for the last several days, I finally managed to feel well enough today and play my NYT games. Aside, but why is this literally the ONLY forum I ever use that frequently throws an error telling me to copy my text, reload the page, and try again?

It must be the weekend because the usual “I hate this puzzle I didn’t know the answers” people seem to be away. Or everyone took 21A to heart and changed their perspective. 
Sorry to see Dallas and Atlanta getting some Canadian style weather. Stay warm!
Seemed easy to me. But then, some Mondays seemed hard.
The foreign elements stymied me for a bit today. BANC, L'ORANGE, and an introduction to "rathskeller". I was able to complete the puzzle, however, and then went to the Goog and educated myself.
The only Rathskeller I know is a notoriously cheap and dirty student bar just off the University of Toronto campus.  I cannot work out how to fit ‘Labatt 50’ in this space.

I thought that was an excellent puzzle! Thanks RL!

Was it hard or easy for me? Well, at first I thought it was hard, but I did not abandon hope. I had about half of it filled in and could not go any further.

I took a nap. When I got back to the puzzle, the answers seemed to just fill in by themselves. So it was hard until it wasn't.

I have posted more or less this same comment a thousand times. For those of you who get totally stumped by a puzzle, take Sam's advice, don't abandon hope. Just put the puzzle down, go do something else, come back later and for some reason your brain will have it all figured it out.

One other thing. I live in Valencia, where we had the devastating floods a few weeks back and thousands of people lost their lives, their homes, their entire neighborhoods, so I may have some idea about how terrible the devastation has been in southern California. 

What can I or anyone say?
Will is back baby, Will is back

@Jennifer

“I’ll never get it” ‘s that “somehow come together” are the best.  Well said!
@Crab me too! Totally agree
@Michael don't forget "many a trial component" @42A which completes a nice trio
@Jamie Well said. Friday and Saturday are my favorite puzzles because they don't suffer from having to brute force a theme into the grid.
@B  I would have loved it if the diagonal black squares had a kink in them to match up with BENDYSTRAW.
@B In the other camp. For this puzzle, the first thing I noticed was the very pleasing grid. I simply admired it for a moment, then I was quite pleased when the fill was equally fun.

@Andrzej @B I don’t usually look at the layout of a grid either, but today’s I happened to notice and my experience was similar to what Nora described—I admired the design of the grid before filling anything in and it enhanced my experience.

Once in a while the grid may intentionally represent something that pertains to the theme, so I can appreciate that.  And sometimes it doesn't represent anything, but still may look unique or interesting to some, and I can appreciate that.  Because of the symmetrical nature of the crossword grid, sometimes people think they see a swastika, but I cannot appreciate that being anything other coincidental.

@B, @Andrjez, I guess I feel about pangrams the same way you do about how a grid looks -- it has nothing to do with the game.

Nice little discussion.  Thanks, all!

What bugs me about the esthetics is the thought that it may be depriving us of otherwise fun, juicy puzzle possibilities.  I'd really find it hard to care less about "puzzle symmetry" than I already do.  Just, why.  Why in the world is that close to a prerequisite for an interactive word game.

Combine that needless restriction with an urge to have the whole grid be pretty, and it's a true wonder we ever get a clever puzzle at all.  I wonder what kind of good stuff we'd be getting if those conventions were lifted and completely discarded...

Respect to the constructors, working with two hands and a toe tied behind their backs.

I don't really understand how a more difficult puzzle would ever take me the same amount of time as a simple one.  Rather than justing filling in blanks as fast as I can read and write, a tougher puzzle entails waiting for crosses, puzzling out unknown names (and there are often many unknown to me) and places, and waiting for inspiration.

 Today, for example, seemed very easy for a Friday, but I didn't know each answer automatically.  I don't think I'll ever know all of the answers in late week puzzles without some crosses.  I actually hope I don't because if I did, it would cease to be entertaining.

@Nancy J. 
Similar.

@Nancy J.

Same, but with a little OCD. And maybe a little ADD.

A few years ago, I decided to prioritize enjoyment of the puzzle over solving speed. Now I fill in only "gimmes" on the first few passes, repeating all Acrosses top to bottom then all Downs left to right. If some Across gimmes are stacked so as to complete a Down, I'll leave one blank to ensure I don't miss reading the Down clue. (The ADD is when I get through several Across/Down cycles and still can't remember some of the crossing clues.)

I absolutely LOVED today's puzzle because the challenge was in the potential misdirects and multiple possible answers. I thought of AARP and STONES on my first pass, but didn't enter them until very near the end.

Because early week cluing is more straightforward, it usually takes fewer passes to validate my answers, and so the time is faster. (My Monday average is half of Friday.)

Very fun to read others' takes. Thanks, @CCNY!

@Cindy 

A little OCD + a bit of ADD 🙋‍♀️

I've always been an across-then-down, left-to-right solver, but sometime in the past year started weaving in a few Downs before I've reached the bottom of the grid-! It started as a quick confirmation, such as the Q possibility for today's holy book, but without entering any text. But then I couldn't always hold the answer in my head (hello, ADD!), so I started typing them in... And my solve times decreased rapidly. Now sometimes Fridays feel too easy. 😳

But either way "watering hole" still doesn't sit well with that type of canteen since it's more about food.

Same with the Rathskeller, from GIs stationed in West Germany. I did my drinking at the NCO Club...which also fit.

@Mean Old Lady 26A is interesting, isn't it? I also thought it meant use the classic spelling for the holy book, but is that Koran, Qoran, Quran Qu'ran or what? Turns out it meant that "suwar" is the "classic" spelling for what translates as "chapter", more usually transliterated as "sura" in my (admittedly limited) experience. 
   I was just getting used to the idea that those 19th century translators of Chinese had tin ears (it's Beijing not Peking!) and now I'm going to have to believe it of the Arabists too?

@RozzieGrandma 

For what it's worth, KORAN is the only spelling of the holy book in Polish.

@Andrzej 

English has been cursed with a succession of Arabic romanization schemes. KORAN is the product of one of the oldest of these, and so counts as a "classic".
@Mean Old Lady Thanks for the AARP info. Will do the same.

@RozzieGrandma 

Oh, and on the "tin ear" of early transliterators of Mandarin: "Pekin"/"Peking" actually dates from the seventeenth century. In part it reflects the real Ming-Dynasty pronunciation (there's been a shift in the central consonant in the last few hundred years), and in part it was a compromise between Mandarin sounds and the Latin alphabet.

... and in part it's because the original transliteration was French, "Pékin". The French "é" is pronounced very much like the "ei" in "Beijing". But when the name was imported into English the accent was lost, and we started pronouncing it as if the first syllable was "pee".

@Oikofuge

If you ever get the chance, you must visit the Pekin Noodle Parlor in Butte, Montana. In business since 1909.

@Turing 
I agree. I also do crosswords for the wordplay, clever use of language, exploiting the fact that the words of the English language have multiple meanings and implications, so it makes you think.

Crosswords with lots of trivia and general knowledge involving popular music, sports and television - these are not really what I look for. The range of what is possible is too large and too various. For example:
My knowledge of major stars includes Pele, George Best and Alex Ferguson. Popular music from the Beatles to about 1980. Very little TV. Classical music from about 1500. And so on. 
I'll remember that in the US a 'squirt' can be a small child, but not the most major of baseball players. Except Babe Ruth.

RozzieGrandma,
I agree, “moral” is not a perfect rhyme for the 2nd pronunciation of “whorl” that I was going for. I’m not a linguist, but I would rate whorl as about 1.3 syllables, and “moral” as usually having around 1.9 in everyday speech. 
For the record, I lean heavy to the non-girly version, but had a botany prof who said whirl so it’s in my brain and I’m fine with either.

Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
@RozzieGrandma Hmm. Native Californian here. I cannot recall hearing anyone from these parts pronounce orange as ornch. It is generally one syllable, skipping over the "a." But it's like ornge.
@B Google agrees with you. And if it's on the internet it has to be true.

B,

I have clearly been hoist with my own petard.
Determining valid rhyming is perhaps the only thing more subjective than assessing the difficulty of a crossword puzzle.
To me, there are no words in the world that rhyme any more closely than do “world” and “girled” (if girled were a word). So if “whorl” for you rhymes with the non-D part of “world”, then in my books it rhymes with girl. The aspirated h (to me) doesn’t disqualify the rhyme. But this is not a petard I will die on (by?) - just curious which of the two vowel sounds people tend to favour :)

@Jacqui J,

Thank you for the stark reminder of why I agonize for weeks spending countless hours putting each of these puzzles together. I am honored and humbled that I got to play a part in brightening your day during such trying times.

You just made my decade. Glad you enjoyed the puzzle. Please take care of yourself and stay safe.

Robert

@Cal Gal 

If going through all the letters doesn't give you the music, then you'll need to look for an error.

My advice?  Examine EVERY vowel.  So many words can be reasonably spelled by changing the vowel.  For example, it took me a while to figure out if it was WEeNS or WEANS.

Also heck out Cs and Ks, as they might replace one another.

Finally, a new one I saw today, S and Z.  LAzE was my first guess over LASE.
